keyTakeAways: Republican leaders, including House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune, have refused to engage in negotiations with Democrats over government funding, maintaining that the shutdown should end on its own terms.

Several rank-and-file Republican lawmakers, such as Sen. Tommy Tuberville, Rep. Jeff Van Drew, and Sen. Jim Justice, have urged President Donald Trump to get more directly involved in resolving the shutdown, citing his influence and perceived ability to broker a deal.
Trump has not personally negotiated with Democratic leaders Chuck Schumer or Hakeem Jeffries since the shutdown began, despite being open to talks under the condition that the government reopens.

Trump has emphasized that he would only negotiate if the government opens, and he has used the shutdown to push through workforce cuts and redirect funding to military and law enforcement, aligning with his broader political agenda.
Democrats, including Hakeem Jeffries, argue that the lack of negotiations is due to Trump’s refusal to engage and claim that he must be involved to end the impasse.
The current standoff marks a departure from past shutdowns, where both parties typically pursued compromise; instead, leaders are now relying on brinkmanship and mutual refusal.
Some GOP lawmakers, like Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, have encouraged Democrats to directly contact Trump, asserting his accessibility and influence.
White House officials believe the Democrats are in disarray and that their strategy has created a political trap, while maintaining that their own position on the shutdown remains unaltered.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As a prolonged government shutdown continues without resolution, several Republican lawmakers are urging President Donald Trump to take a more direct role in negotiations with Democrats, arguing that his influence and leadership are essential to ending the impasse. While top Republican leaders like House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune have maintained a firm stance against any negotiations, citing the need to preserve their position and refuse concessions, rank-and-file Republicans and Democrats alike are pushing for Trump’s involvement. Trump has not personally engaged in negotiations but has signaled openness to talks under the condition that the government reopens. The shutdown has also been used as a platform for Trump to implement deep cuts to the federal workforce and redirect funding to military and law enforcement, reinforcing his political agenda. Despite calls from Democrats and some GOP senators for direct intervention, Republican leadership remains resolute, projecting confidence that their strategy will prevail, while signaling growing internal unease about the political and societal costs of the standoff.
title: ‘We absolutely need him’: Some in GOP say it’s time for Trump to get involved in shutdown talks even as leaders rebuff idea
